metadata.title: Nanomaterials: Efficient Bifunctional Electrocatalysts for Overall Water Splitting

sections.text:
fu ll p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim wileyonlinelibrary.com (1 of 10) 1606585
1. Introduction
The continued rise in energy demand worldwide and our over-reliance on the limited supplies of fossil fuels (i.e., coal, petroleum, natural gas, etc.) as well as their continued negative environmental impacts have left researchers no choice but to delve into extensive searches for alternative energy options.[1] Among the available options, hydrogen (H2), a clean, carbon-free and renewable energy carrier, is regarded as one of the most ideal alternative energy carriers for the future, because it has a high gravimetric energy density, can be cleanly produced from water, and its only byproduct—after complete combustion/oxidation producing energy—is water.[2] However, the production of hydrogen is currently done by methane reforming reaction, which still relies on fossil fuels and suffers from similar energy challenges as other nonrenewable sectors.[3] On the contrary, the generation of hydrogen with electrochemical water splitting does not do so,
especially if the energy driving the reaction comes from renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar energy. Hence, this reaction remains one of the most promising and appealing technologies for sustainable production of hydrogen from the clean, renewable, and abundant source of hydrogen, i.e., water. However, the wider application of this reaction is currently hampered by two major technical bottlenecks, namely (i) the kinetically and thermodynamically sluggish anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in it and (ii) the instability, high cost, and less earth-abundance of noble metal-based materials, such as platinum and ruthenium(IV) oxide, which are commonly used as electrocatalysts in conventional water splitting electrolyzers.[4] So, low-cost, efficient, and stable noble metal-free OER electrocatalysts are extremely desired to accelerate the development of overall water splitting green energy conversion systems.
Recently, some research efforts have been devoted to finding active and robust earth-abundant OER electrocatalysts with an ability to reduce the overpotential of the reaction, and thus make the water splitting process cost-effective and more energy-efficient. Among non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts,

sections.heading: N-, O-, and S-Tridoped Carbon-Encapsulated Co9S8 Nanomaterials: Efficient Bifunctional Electrocatalysts for
Senchuan Huang, Yuying Meng,* Shiman He, Anandarup Goswami, Qili Wu, Junhao Li,
Shengfu Tong, Tewodros Asefa,* and Mingmei Wu*
sections.text: The development of highly active and stable earth-abundant catalysts to reduce or eliminate the reliance on noble-metal based ones in green and sustainable (electro)chemical processes is nowadays of great interest. Here, N-, O-, and S-tridoped carbon-encapsulated Co9S8 (Co9S8@NOSC) nanomaterials are synthesized via simple pyrolysis of S- and Co(II)-containing polypyrrole solid precursors, and the materials are proven to serve as noble metal-free bifunctional electrocatalysts for water splitting in alkaline medium. The nanomaterials exhibit remarkable catalytic performances for oxygen evolution reaction in basic electrolyte, with small overpotentials, high anodic current densities, low Tafel slopes as well as very high (nearly 100%) Faradic efficiencies. Moreover, the materials are found to efficiently electrocatalyze hydrogen evolution reaction in acidic as well as basic solutions, showing high activity in both cases and maintaining good stability in alkaline medium.

sections.heading: A two-electrode electrolyzer assembled using the material synthesized at
sections.text:
900 °C (Co9S8@NOSC-900) as an electrocatalyst at both electrodes gives current densities of 10 and 20 mA cm−2 at potentials of 1.60 and 1.74 V, respectively. The excellent electrocatalytic activity exhibited by the materials is proposed to be mainly due to the synergistic effects between the Co9S8 nanoparticles cores and the heteroatom-doped carbon shells in the materials.
DOI: 10.1002/adfm.201606585
S. Huang, Dr. Y. Meng, S. He, Q. Wu, J. Li, Dr. S. Tong, Prof. M. Wu School of Chemistry Sun Yat-Sen University No. 135, Xingang Xi Road Guangzhou 510275, P. R. China E-mail: mengyuy@mail.sysu.edu.cn; ceswmm@mail.sysu.edu.cn Prof. A. Goswami CoExAMMPC and Division of Chemistry Department of Sciences and Humanities Vignan’s Foundation for Science Technology and Research (VFSTR) University Vignan’s University Vadlamudi, Guntur, 522 213 Andhra Pradesh, India Prof. T. Asefa Department of Chemistry and Chemical Biology and Department of Chemical and Biochemical Engineering, Rutgers The State University of New Jersey 610 Taylor Road, Piscataway, NJ 08854, USA E-mail: tasefa@rci.rutgers.edu
www.afm-journal.de
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
www.advancedsciencenews.com
fu ll
p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwileyonlinelibrary.com1606585 (2 of 10)
nickel (Ni) and cobalt (Co)-based materials have been particularly extensively investigated, due to their earth-abundance, environmental-friendliness, and high catalytic activity, and thus potential to replace RuO2 and IrO2 catalysts in commercial electrolyzers.[5] Among catalytically active materials based on Co and Ni, perhaps the relatively newer additions include their chalcogenides (sulfides and selenides) and the hybrid derivatives of their chalcogenides with other materials. For instance, a Co-based nanocomposite material comprising CoSe2 nanobelts supported on nitrogen-doped reduced graphene oxide was reported to exhibit a good electrocatalytic activity toward OER in alkaline medium, with a low overpotential of 290 mV and a small Tafel slope of ≈40 mV dec−1.[6] In another example, Zhang and co-workers found that a composite electrode composed of Ni3S2 nanorods/Ni foam could serve as a high-performance OER electrocatalyst, with a small overpotential of ≈157 mV.[7] Despite such promising reports, substantial efforts are still needed to improve the activity and stability of known non-noble metal-based or metal-free electrocatalysts as well as to find newer ones with good catalytic performances for OER.
While metal chalcogenides are prevailing in the OER literature, another class of materials comprising metal/metal carbide nanoparticles encapsulated by heteroatoms-doped carbon materials have also been making strides as highly promising and stable electrocatalysts for OER, oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), and hydrogen evolution reaction (HER).[8] Notably, Zelenay and co-workers[9] reported that transition metal particles encapsulated with onion-like N-doped carbon nanoshells could serve as excellent nonprecious ORR electrocatalysts both in acidic and basic media with an electron transfer number close to 4, giving H2O with a yield of ≈99%. Bao and coworkers[10] found that nonprecious metal nanoparticles encapsulated with N-doped carbon materials could efficiently help the electrocatalysis of HER over a wide pH range and OER in alkaline electrolyte with excellent stability. Thanks to their unique nanostructures and the facile electron transport existing in their large interfaces, the metallic nanoparticles cores and the carbon shells in these materials synergistically enhance the electrocatalytic processes involved in the reactions.[11] Besides, carbon nanomaterials (shells) doped with heteroatoms, such as N, S, and O, can possess unique electronic structures and lower local work function. This, in turn, can promote the adsorption of intermediates on the surfaces of material during electrocatalytic reaction and improve the electron transfer between catalyst surfaces and reaction intermediates, resulting in increased electrocatalytic activity.[12] In addition, the doped carbon shells can effectively protect the nanoparticle cores from undergoing dissolution and aggregation, and thereby significantly improving the stability of the material during electrocatalytic reactions.
Despite the prominent progress made in the exploration of carbon-encapsulated metal or metal carbide nanoparticles for electrocatalysis of HER in acidic medium or OER in alkaline solutions, to the best of our knowledge, there are only a few reports of heteroatom-doped carbon-encapsulated metal carbide/chalcogenide nanostructures, especially bifunctional ones with electrocatalytic activities toward both HER and OER.[13]
Such hybrid nanostructured materials can be expected to have high electrocatalytic performances stemming from the metal chalcogenide or metal carbide nanoparticles, the high
conductivity in the material, and the great stability of the nanoparticles due to the protective heteroatom-doped carbon layers around them. This also means, such materials can be expected to find practical applications as electrocatalysts in alkaline water electrolyzers. Intrigued by this idea and the recent report that intrinsic metallic Co9S8 nanomaterials exhibit catalytic activity for OER or HER separately in different media,[14] we envisioned that encapsulating them with heteroatoms-doped carbon materials could lead to ideal candidate electrocatalyst for overall water splitting with high catalytic activity and long-term stability. To this end, herein we present a simple straightforward synthesis of nitrogen, oxygen, and sulfur tri-doped carbon-encapsulated Co9S8 nanoparticles, which we dubbed Co9S8@NOSC, and their robust bifunctional electrocatalytic properties toward both OER and HER in alkaline media. Furthermore, we demonstrate the materials’ ability to function as electrocatalysts for both OER and HER, at both electrodes of a single water electrolyzer, effectively generating both H2 and O2 gases at the same time.

sections.heading: 2. Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The Co9S8@NOSC nanocomposite materials were synthesized by preparing a solid-phase precursor composed of S- and Co(II)containing polypyrrole (S-Co-PPY), carbonizing the S-Co-PPY at different high temperatures, and then immersing the carbonized products in concentrated HCl solution to remove surface bound metallic species, as illustrated in Scheme 1. Specifically, the synthesis process involved three major steps: (i) polymerization of pyrrole using (NH4)2S2O8 (which served as an oxidant as well as a source of S), and complexation of Co(II) ions with the resulting S-containing polypyrrole (S-PPY); (ii) high temperature treatment of the resulting S-Co-PPY at 600, 700, 800, 900, or 980 °C under inert atmosphere (Ar) so that it can undergo metal-assisted carbonization; and finally, (iii) removal of the nonencapsulated cobalt species from the surfaces of the carbonized products using aqueous HCl solution (see the Supporting Information for more detailed procedure). This procedure led to Co9S8@NOSC-T materials, in which T represents the pyrolysis temperature (or 600, 700, 800, 900, or 980 °C). Besides these materials, Co9S8@NOSC materials containing different amounts of Co9S8, named Co9S8@NOSC-R, were synthesized by varying the initial molar ratios of pyrrole-toCo(II) in the solid precursors and then pyrolyzing them at the optimal pyrolysis temperature of 900 °C (Table S1, Supporting Information). Additionally, for comparison, a control material, heteroatom-doped carbon containing no metal or metal chalcogenide, was synthesized from S-PPY precursor without Co(II) ions in it, by following similar procedures as above and pyrolyzing the precursor at 900 °C (see the in the Supporting Information).
The obtained materials were all systemically characterized by various techniques. First, X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the Co9S8@NOSC-T materials before being subjected to HCl washing were obtained. The results (Figure S1, Supporting Information) illustrated that all the materials exhibited similar XRD patterns, with peaks that can be assigned to crystalline pentlandite Co9S8 (PDF#75-2023) as well as Co phase (PDF#15-0806), indicating the co-presence of Co9S8 and Co(0)
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
fu ll p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim wileyonlinelibrary.com (3 of 10) 1606585
nanoparticles in the materials. The XRD patterns of the materials after being etched with 1 m HCl solution for 24 h were then obtained (Figure 1a and Figure S2a, Supporting Information). In this case, the diffraction peaks matched only with phase-pure cubic Co9S8 (PDF#75-2023), or no characteristic XRD peaks associated with crystal Co was observed, suggesting that the Co metal species formed during the pyrolysis process must have been completely etched during acid-wash. In addition, no noticeable carbon peaks were observed in all the XRD patterns, presumably because of their relatively weak intensities compared with those of the crystalline Co9S8. On the other hand, the XRD pattern of N, S, O tri-doped carbon material
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
Scheme 1. Synthetic procedures used to synthesize Co9S8@NOSC hybrid electrocatalysts.
fu ll
p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwileyonlinelibrary.com1606585 (4 of 10)
(NOSC or the control material) derived solely from S-PPY precursor (Figure S2b, Supporting Information) showed only two broad diffraction peaks at 2θ of ≈26.6° and 43.5°, which can be indexed as the (002) and (101) plane reflections of graphite-like structure and disordered amorphous carbon (PDF#41-1487), respectively. Peaks associated with crystalline Co9S8 were not seen in the XRD pattern of this material. The large intensity ratio of the peaks associated (002) to (101) planes indicated that the NOSC material had a high degree of graphitization and was primarily composed of graphitic carbon.
Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images (Figure 1c) of Co9S8@NOSC-900 hybrid materials showed dark spots, presumably Co9S8, that were surrounded by lighter regions or layers of NOSC. A high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Figure 1d) revealed the presence of cubic crystalline Co9S8 possessing lattice fringes of 2.98 and 2.21 Å, which correspond to the (113) and (0–24) crystallographic planes, respectively, of Co9S8. It is worth adding here that the angle between the (113) facet and the (0–24) facet obtained along the [5–2–1] crystallographic direction of Co9S8 was found to be about 47.6°, which is in accordance with the theoretical value in crystalline Co9S8. Furthermore, in the HRTEM images in Figure 1d and Figure S3 in the Supporting Information, the Co9S8 particles could be seen tightly wrapped by graphene-like carbon shell whose thickness ranged from 2 to 6 nm and which consisted of multiple graphitic layers. This intimate contact between the Co9S8 nanoparticles and the NOSC shells should be able to help the Co9S8 nanoparticles avoid contacting oxygen, or prevent them from undergoing oxidation. Besides, the NOSC shells should be able to inhibit the particles from undergoing possible agglomeration.
Elemental mapping with scanning TEM energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (STEMEDX) was performed to obtain the elemental distribution of C, N, O, Co, and S in the materials. In the results, regions containing C, N, and O atoms, and other regions rich with S and Co were observed (Figure 1f–j). While the C, N, and O were seen uniformly distributed throughout the material, the Co and S atoms were seen localized only in few regions. This is in accordance with the presence of Co9S8 crystals encapsulated by heteroatom-doped carbon matrix, as observed in HRTEM images. The corresponding EDX (Figure 1b) obtained from the selected square in the image as displayed in Figure 1c revealed that the molar ratio of Co:S was ≈1.01, a value that is slightly smaller than the theoretical value of 1.13 (or 9:8) in Co9S8, suggesting the possible incorporation of some S atoms in the carbon layers. Unlike Co9S8@NOSC, the control material NOSC showed no core–shell like structure, but rather the typical morphology of the graphitic carbon (Figure 1e and Figure S4, Supporting Information). Comparison of the SEM images of Co9S8@NOSC-900 and NOSC showed no major morphological difference between the two materials and
interconnected nanoparticles with diameters of 50–100 nm in both cases (Figure S5, Supporting Information). Besides, the Brunauer_Emmett-Teller (BET) surface areas of all the Co9S8@ NOSC and NOSC materials obtained from the N2 adsorption and desorption isotherms ranged from 15 to 29 m2 g−1, with Co9S8@NOSC-900 showing the highest BET surface area of 29 m2 g−1 (Figure S6, Supporting Information).
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) of the materials was performed in air atmosphere to investigate their compositions (Figure S7, Supporting Information). A weight loss below 200 °C was observed in the materials, which was ascribed to surface adsorbed water. The observed weight loss between 200 and 500 °C was attributed to the combustion of the NOSC shells. An increase in weight, followed by a decrease in weight, observed between 500 and 800 °C was ascribed to an initial oxidation of Co9S8 to CoSO4 and the subsequent decomposition of CoSO4 to Co3O4. This is supported by the XRD patterns of the products obtained after TGA (Figure S8, Supporting Information) as well as based on results recently reported in the literature.[15] Moreover, when going from Co9S8@NOSC-600 to Co9S8@NOSC-980 by raising the pyrolysis temperature, the mass of Co gradually increased from 21.4% to 42.4%, which is due to the higher loss of hydrocarbons upon the materials’ treatment at higher temperature.
X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to analyze the surface compositions and the chemical states of Co9S8@ NOSC materials. The XPS survey spectrum showed main peaks centered at 161.2, 284.6, 398.4, 531.1, and 777.9 eV, which could be assigned to S2p, C1s, N1s, O1s, and Co2p, respectively (Figure 2a and Figure S9a, Supporting Information). The
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
fu ll p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim wileyonlinelibrary.com (5 of 10) 1606585
O atoms in the materials were probably due to the oxygen-containing groups present on the materials or the oxygen atoms incorporated into the graphitic structure of the materials, both of which are commonly observed in carbon materials, as we and others reported previously.[12b,16] Quantitative analysis of the Co9S8@NOSC materials indicated that the Co:S molar ratios in the materials are all <9/8, which is consistent with the results obtained with EDX analysis, confirming once again that there must have been some extra sulfur atoms in the materials, besides those in Co9S8, or some S atoms must have been incorporated as dopants into the carbon shells. The N:C atomic ratio was found to decrease significantly (from 0.28 to 0.06) when the pyrolysis temperature was increased from 600 to 980 °C (Figure 2b). This is in line with the results reported previously[17] and suggests that more N atoms, as compared to carbon, were lost during high temperature pyrolysis of PPY precursor. However, the O:C, S:C, and Co:C atomic ratios were all found to initially increase but then decrease at higher temperatures, making Co9S8@NOSC-700, which was pyrolyzed at 700 °C, to possess the highest amount of O, S, and Co (0.5, 0.11, and 0.08, respectively) among the materials we synthesized and investigated here. The increase in the amount of S in the materials when the pyrolysis temperature was raised from 600 to 700 °C could be due to the decomposition of S and Co from the Co9S8 nanoparticles cores and their gradual incorporation into the carbon shells. The decrease in the amount of S in the materials when the pyrolysis temperature was increased above 700 °C could be ascribed to the higher rate of loss of S atoms from Co9S8, compared with the incorporation of the S atoms into the carbon matrix.
Additionally, Co9S8@NOSC-R materials, which were prepared by varying the initial molar ratio of pyrrole-to-Co(II) in the precursors (see Table S1 in the Supporting Information), were characterized. The materials include Co9S8@NOSC-900, which was discussed above and which was prepared from an initial reagent molar ratio of (NH4)2S2O8:pyrrole:CoCl2·6H2O of 4:2:1, denoted here as Co9S8@NOSC-4/2/1 to help the discussions. As can be seen in Figure S9b in the Supporting Information, this material had the highest amount of Co and S compared with the other Co9S8@NOSC-R materials, whose R corresponds to 6/3/1 and 8/4/3. This suggests that Co9S8@ NOSC-4/2/1 had the highest content of Co9S8 as compared with the other two materials. Hence, it could be said that the use of higher amount of Co(II) in the precursor with sufficient source of S (persulfate) did not necessarily lead to more carbon-encapsulated Co9S8 in the materials, beyond what was achieved in Co9S8@NOSC-4/2/1 (or Co9S8@NOSC-900). We believe that, although more Co(II) in the precursor is expectedly favorable for the formation of Co9S8 particles, in this case most of the particles reside outside the carbon layers and dissolve during the treatment of the resulting Co9S8@NOSC materials in HCl solution, leaving behind only those Co9S8 particles encapsulated within the heteroatom-doped carbons. It is worth adding that no peak associated with Co was observed in the XPS survey spectra of the control material NOSC, as expected (Figure S10, Supporting Information).
The high-resolution XPS spectra of C1s for Co9S8@NOSC-T materials are displayed in Figure S11 in the Supporting Information. All the C1s peaks are further deconvoluted into four peaks, corresponding to CCC (284.6 eV), CS (285.7 eV), CO/CN (286.6 eV) and CO (288.3 eV) species.[18] The observed peaks associated with CN and CS moieties suggested that N and S atoms were successfully incorporated into the carbon structures. The peaks corresponding to CO and CO indicated the presence of COH and C(O)OH species in the materials, whose O atoms must have come from the persulfate ions included in the precursors. When the pyrolysis temperature was increased, the percentage of CCC in the materials significantly increased, while the proportions of CN/CO and CS species gradually decreased (Figure S14, Supporting Information). This suggests that a higher pyrolysis temperature favors not only the graphitization of carbon but also the loss of heteroatom dopants, and thereby an increase in vacancy defect sites in the materials. In the case of the highresolution XPS spectra of N1s of the Co9S8@NOSC materials (Figure S12, Supporting Information), three main peaks associated with pyridinic-N (398.3 eV), pyrrolic-N (400.1 eV), and quaternary-N (400.9 eV) species were observed.[19] When the pyrolysis temperature was raised from 600 to 980 °C, the percentage of the quaternary-N peak gradually increased, while the pyrrolic-N peak showed an opposite trend (Figure S14b, Supporting Information). Meanwhile, the pyridinic-N peak increased when pyrolysis temperature was increased from 600 to 700 °C, but then decreased when the temperature was increased from 700 to 980 °C. It is worth noting that, in XPS spectrum of Co9S8@NOSC-600, only pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N peaks but no quaternary-N peak were seen. Upon increasing the pyrolysis temperature from 600 to 700 °C, besides pyridinic-N and pyrrolic-N peaks, a quaternary-N peak started to appear. However, when the pyrolysis temperature was further increased above 800 °C, the pyrrolic-N peak was not observed but rather only pyridinic-N and quaternary-N peaks were seen. The appearance of quaternary-N and the disappearance of pyrrolic-N is simply due to the increasing tendency of transformation of the PPYoriginated pyrrolic-N species into quaternary-N species at high pyrolysis temperatures.[20] In case of deconvoluted S2p spectra (Figure S13, Supporting Information), the measured peaks at binding energies of 161.3 and 162.4 eV, with energy splitting value of 1.1 eV, could be attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 core levels of S2−, respectively, primarily arising from Co9S8.[21] Meanwhile, the peaks at 163.0 and 164.1 eV in the spectra were attributed to the 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 of S atoms in CSC, and the peak centered at 169.1 eV was assigned to the oxidized S species, labeled as SOxn−.[22] The presence of CSC in the XPS spectra demonstrated that S atoms were indeed doped into the graphitic carbon shells, besides forming the tri-doped carbonencapsulated Co9S8 nanoparticles, whereas the existence of SOxn− indicated the presence of some sulfate/sulfite moieties in the materials due to the possible partial oxidation of S. The percentage of CSC and S2− species (the latter corresponding to the S species in Co8S9), as can be seen in Figure S14c in the Supporting Information, first decreased with increasing pyrolysis temperature from 600 to 800 °C but then increased after 800 °C. In the case of the deconvoluted spectrum of Co2p3/2 peak, the two peaks located at 778.4 and 781.7 eV were attributed to metallic CoCo and oxidized Co (i.e., CoS groups, in which Co has Co2+ and Co3+ oxidation states).[23] The peak centered at 786.5 eV was due to the shake-up satellite peak of Co2+,
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
fu ll
p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwileyonlinelibrary.com1606585 (6 of 10)
indicating the formation of octahedrally coordinated, high-spin Co2+ in crystalline Co9S8.[24] The high-resolution XPS spectra of Co9S8@NOSC-R and the control material NOSC were also obtained, and the results are presented in Figures S15–S18 in the Supporting Information. The spectrum of Co9S8@NOSC4/2/1 (i.e., Co9S8@NOSC-900) clearly showed that this material had the highest proportions of CCC, pyridinic-N, and Co9S8. Therefore, based on TEM, EDX, and XPS results, we concluded that the synthesized Co9S8@NOSC nanocomposite materials containing homogeneously dispersed nanocrystalline Co9S8 particles that are encapsulated with conductive heteroatomsdoped carbon substrates might be conducive for high-performance electrocatalysis.
Raman spectroscopy was used further to characterize the composition and the degree of graphitization of the materials (Figure 2c and Figure S19, Supporting Information). In the spectra, two sharp Raman peaks at 1354 and 1584 cm−1 that are characteristic of carbon materials and that can be ascribed to the disordered structures/structural defects (or D band) and the graphitic G band, respectively, were observed. Furthermore, a relatively weaker peak in the lower wavenumber region (at ≈670 cm−1) that can be attributed to Co9S8[15,25] was observed. This peak was absent in the spectrum of the control sample NOSC (Figure S20, Supporting Information). The structural defects present that gave rise to the D band in the materials may have likely to do with the presence of N, O, and S dopants and the concomitant absence of some graphitic carbon atoms in the materials.
The ID/IG ratio of Co9S8@NOSC-T materials, which is determined from the Raman spectra and which is related to the degree of disordered/ordered of carbon structure of the materials, decreased from 0.88 to 0.82 when the pyrolysis temperature was raised from 600 to 980 °C. The result illustrated that a higher pyrolysis temperature led to a higher degree of graphitization in the materials, which is in agreement with the aforementioned XPS results. The ID/IG ratio of Co9S8@NOSC-900 (≈0.82) was lower than that of NOSC (≈0.87), which means the former had a higher degree of ordered carbon structure than the latter and that Co species formed during the pyrolysis process might have facilitated the formation of graphitic carbons on the surface of Co9S8.[26] Meanwhile, the ID/IG ratio gradually decreased (from 0.84 to 0.76) as the amount of Co(II) used for the synthesis of the materials was increased (that is, when going from Co9S8@NOSC-6/3/1 to Co9S8@NOSC-8/4/3). This suggested again that the higher amount of Co species used in the synthesis of the materials was beneficial for the formation of more ordered carbon or graphitic structure during the pyrolysis processes. This, in turn, was expected to have favorable effects on the electrical conductivity of the materials, and possibly also their electrocatalytic properties.
The electrocatalytic properties of the materials for various reactions were then investigated. First, the electrocatalytic properties toward OER of all the as-prepared Co9S8@ NOSC materials were evaluated in 1 m KOH solution using a typical three-electrode cell configuration. In the cell, a glassy carbon electrode (GCE) with homogeneously coated sample (0.28 mg cm−2), a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode and a graphitic carbon rod were used as the working electrode, reference and counter electrodes, respectively. For comparison, similar
measurements were carried out over bare GCE, NOSC material, Co9S8 nanoparticles, and commercial RuO2 under otherwise identical conditions. The polarization curve without iR-compensation obtained over Co9S8@NOSC-900 exhibited that this material had remarkable electrocatalytic performance for OER, showing a small onset potential of 1.40 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode, which corresponds to an overpotential of 170 mV, and giving high current densities (Figure 3a). Notably also, after normalized with geometric surface area, the Co9S8@NOSC-900 hybrid material afforded a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (a metric relevant to solar fuel synthesis)[27] at a small overpotential of 340 mV, which is close enough to that of commercial RuO2 electrocatalyst (Figure S23, Supporting Information) and comparable with those of some of the efficient noble metal-free OER electrocatalysts recently reported (Table S2, Supporting Information). However, the sole Co9S8 nanoparticles, NOSC, and the physical mixture of Co9S8 and NOSC (mass ratio of 1:4) required larger overpotentials of 510, 430, and 370 mV, respectively to achieve the same current density (10 mA cm−2) (Figure S24, Supporting Information). So, although the metallic Co9S8 and NOSC nanomaterials as well as their physical mixtures could all electrocatalyze OER, none of them matched Co9S8@NOSC in terms of catalytic performance for OER. The unique heteroatom-doped carbon-encapsulated Co9S8 must have significantly enhanced the electrocatalytic activity, most likely due to the synergistic effects in it between the embedded Co9S8 cores and the NOSC shells and the close surface contact between them (see further discussions below). Specifically, their higher degree of charge transport and better conductivity as well as ability to adsorb/desorb reactants/intermediates (i.e., HO*, O*, and HOO*)[28] may have most likely made Co9S8@NOSC’s to show greater catalytic activity toward OER. Besides, the tri-doped carbon shells could protect the encapsulated Co9S8 nanoparticles from undergoing oxidation and aggregation, resulting in their excellent stability during electrocatalysis under the alkaline media (vide infra).
A nickel foam decorated with Co9S8@NOSC-900, named Co9S8@NOSC-900/NF, was also tested for OER in a three-electrode cell, and its catalytic performance was found to be higher than a nickel foam electrode (Figure S25, Supporting Information). Notably, Co9S8@NOSC-900/NF needed much smaller overpotentials of 330 and 420 mV (for a loading amount of 5 mg cm−2 at a scan rate of 5 mV s−1) to give current densities of 20 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively.
In order to determine the effect of the pyrolysis temperature on the electrocatalytic performances of these materials for OER, the electrocatalytic properties of different Co9S8@NOSC materials derived from the same ratio of pyrrole-to-Co(II) ion but with different pyrolysis temperatures (Co9S8@NOSC-T) were evaluated. As can be seen in Figure 3a, with increasing pyrolysis temperature, the electrocatalytic activity of the materials gradually improved, i.e., the onset potential shifted to more negative values and the current density at a given potential increased. Among the materials we synthesized and tested, the one pyrolyzed at 900 °C, in particular, exhibited the best electrocatalytic activity. That means, at the same current density, the overpotential needed for Co9S8@NOSC-900 for OER was much smaller than those needed for the other materials under the same conditions, as shown in Figure 3b.
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
fu ll p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim wileyonlinelibrary.com (7 of 10) 1606585
The Tafel plots (log j vs η) were obtained from the corresponding linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curves to explore the OER kinetics for the electrocatalysts, according to the Tafel equation (η = b log j + a, where η is the overpotential, j is the current density and b is the Tafel slope). The Tafel slope of Co9S8@NOSC-900 (68 mV dec−1) was only slightly higher than that of commercial RuO2 (45 mV dec−1) and smaller than those of other Co9S8@NOSC-T materials, implying that Co9S8@ NOSC-900 possessed an outstanding intrinsic OER kinetic profile. Besides, Co9S8@NOSC-900 gave the highest mass activity and turnover frequency (TOF) value (Table 1 and Figure S26, Supporting Information). The small overpotential, high current density, large mass activity, and TOF, as well as low/small Tafel slope all indicated Co9S8@NOSC-900’s very good electrocatalytic activity toward OER.
To gain further insight into the electrocatalytic activity of the above electrocatalysts, the electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) and electrochemical surface areas (ECSA) of the electrocatalysts were obtained. In the Nyquist plots (Figure S28, Supporting Information) of Co9S8@NOSC-T samples, Co9S8@NOSC900 could be clearly seen to have the smallest semicircle (with the smallest radius) or the smallest charge transfer resistance (Rct) compared with the other electrocatalysts (Table 1). This suggested that the electron transfer rate during OER was faster in Co9S8@NOSC-900, the material obtained at 900 °C, than in those obtained at the other pyrolysis temperatures we used. Moreover, the Rct of NOSC, Co9S8, and the physical mixture of the two materials were much higher than that of Co9S8@ NOSC-900 (Figure S28b, Supporting Information), revealing the importance of strong interactions between NOSC layers and Co9S8 cores in enhancing the electron transport rates and in giving higher electrocatalytic activity. Based on the above results, we concluded that the excellent catalytic activity toward OER exhibited by Co9S8@NOSC-900 was due to the enhanced electrical conductivity provided to the material by the NOSC shells and the synergistic effect formed between Co9S8 nanoparticles cores and NOSC shells in the material. Co9S8@NOSC-900’s excellent catalytic activity toward OER was further evaluated by comparing the values of ECSA of all the Co9S8@NOSC-T and Co9S8@ NOSC-R materials among one another. The ECSA is proportional to the double layer capacitance, as per ECSA ≈ Cdl/Cs, where Cdl is the double layer capacitance and Cs is the capacitance of an atomically smooth planar electrocatalyst surface per unit area under identical conditions (see the Supporting Information).[29] The ECSA was measured also to
in the Supporting Information and Table 1, the value of ECSA of Co9S8@NOSC-900 (245 cm2) was much larger than those of the other Co9S8@NOSC-T materials (whose values are 18, 34, 103, and 162 cm2 for pyrolysis temperature of 600, 700, 800, and 980 °C, respectively), suggesting that Co9S8@NOSC-900 had more exposed catalytically active sites for electrolysis during OER. This is perhaps also why, among the series of Co9S8@NOSC-R materials, Co9S8@NOSC-4/2/1 (or Co9S8@NOSC-900) gave the best electrocatalytic performance for OER with a small overpotential and Tafel slope (Figure S27, Supporting Information). Besides its largest value of ECSA, its smallest value of impedance (Figure S28c, S30, Supporting Information and Table 1) and its highest content of Co9S8 may have all contributed to Co9S8@ NOSC-900’s highest electrocatalytic activity. Furthermore, although Co9S8@NOSC-900 does not possess the highest
Adv. Funct. Mater. 2017, 1606585
fu ll
p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheimwileyonlinelibrary.com1606585 (8 of 10)
amount of heteroatom-doped carbon-encapsulated Co9S8, it has a relatively higher density of CCC and a higher degree of conductivity, and hence offers better synergistic catalytic effects and better electrocatalytic performance.
The long-term stability of electrocatalysts is a crucial criterion for them to find practical applications. Hence, the durability of Co9S8@NOSC-900 during electrocatalysis of OER was evaluated with chronoamperometry at overpotential of 340 mV. Figure 3d showed that the current density over the material in OER barely decreased after a 10 h long continuous operation. Additionally, the LSV curve and Tafel slope (68 mV dec−1) of the electrocatalyst after 10 h reaction time remained almost the same, compared with the original ones (Figure 2e,f). However, Co9S8 and the physical mixture of NOSC and Co9S8 electrocatalysts gave significantly lower current density, by as much as 65% and 84%, respectively, compared with those of the original ones after the same time period in the reaction (Figure S31, Supporting Information). Co9S8@NOSC-900’s long-term stability during electrocatalysis of OER under the relatively harsh basic reaction condition was most likely due to its NOSC shells or the shells’ ability to prevent the Co9S8 nanoparticles cores from undergoing corrosion. In fact, TEM images of the electrocatalyst collected and imaged after these tests (Figure S32, Supporting Information) showed that the Co9S8@NOSC material still remained to have core–shell like structure, without exposed Co9S8 nanoparticles and with its structure and morphology remaining intact.
The Faradaic efficiency during OER was determined with chronoamperometry over a period of 120 min. The experimentally measured amount of dioxygen (O2) in this time period was found to be comparable with the theoretically calculated quantity based on the charge consumed during electrocatalysis, indicating ≈100% Faradic efficiency of the catalytic reaction (Figure S33, Supporting Information). Thus, Co9S8@NOSC nanomaterials can be said to be promising high-performance, earth abundant noble metal-free-based electrocatalysts for OER under alkaline conditions.
Based on the above experimental results, the excellent OER performance of Co9S8@NOSC electrocatalyst could be attributed to the following five factors: (i) the inherently catalytically active Co9S8 nanoparticles may have played a synergistic role in the electrochemical OER in alkaline medium by the virtue of the unique nanointerfaces they form with the heteroatom-
doped carbon shells, as core–shell structures. Such combination between metallic nanoparticles and layered conductive material not only brings together the properties of the two types of materials, but also produces synergistic effects that are useful for electrocatalysts;[30] (ii) the nanointerfaces formed between the Co9S8 cores and the heteroatom-doped carbon shells can constitute good donor-acceptor electronic interactions, where the electrons of the Co9S8 nanoparticles can transfer to the heteroatom-doped carbon surfaces. This, in turn, greatly alters the electronic properties of the heteroatom-doped carbon shells and optimizes the electron transfer between electrocatalyst surfaces and reaction intermediates, leading to increased activity toward electrocatalysis. (iii) heteroatom doping in carbon-based materials can decrease the work function of carbon, promoting the adsorption of intermediates on carbon’s surface and possibly reducing the binding energy between the reaction intermediate (i.e., HO*, O*, and HOO*) and the electrocatalyst surface, and finally making the graphitic carbon layer more active for OER;[31] (iv) the NOSC protective layer possesses good conductivity, making the transport of electrons from catalytically active sites to electrode much easier; and (v) the large effective ECSA is beneficial for introduction of more catalytically active sites in the material. Although density functional theory calculation is desirable for further understanding of the electrocatalysis mechanisms in these materials, the possible processes proposed above reasonably account for the higher catalytic activity and the durability of the nonprecious electrocatalysts reported here in OER electrocatalysis.
Besides its electrocatalytic properties for OER in alkaline media, Co9S8@NOSC’s electrocatalytic properties for HER in both acidic and basic solutions were investigated. This was carried out in 0.5 m H2SO4 and 1 m KOH solution, again using a three-electrode cell. Co9S8@NOSC-900 was found to require overpotentials of 235 and 320 mV to deliver a current density of 10 mA cm−2 in HER in 0.5 m H2SO4 and 1 m KOH electrolytes, respectively (Figure S34, Supporting Information). The corresponding Tafel slopes of the materials were found to be 72 and 105 mV dec−1, respectively, indicating that the material gives rise to fast reaction kinetics in HER as well. Moreover, the electrocatalyst remains fairly stable during HER under basic condition. As shown in Figure S37 in the Supporting Information, there is only a slight loss of catalytic activity, even after running the reactions for 20 h. The TEM images

fu ll p a p er
© 2017 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim wileyonlinelibrary.com (9 of 10) 1606585
(Figure S38, Supporting Information) of the material collected after being used as electrocatalyst for 20 h in HER showed that the material remained stable and retained its core–shell type structure. However, some reduction in current density was observed after 12 h long reaction in acidic electrolyte, which may due to the gradual dissolution of Co9S8 nanoparticles in the acidic solution.
Finally, the material’s ability to serve as a bifunctional catalyst for overall water-splitting was investigated by assembling a two-electrode alkaline electrolyzer in 1 m KOH solution, in which a nickel foam-supported Co9S8@NOSC-900 (with a catalyst loading of 5 mg cm−2) was employed as electrocatalyst both at the anode and the cathode sides of the electrolyzer. This electrolyzer delivered current densities of 10 and 20 mA cm−2 at ≈1.60 and 1.74 V, respectively, at room temperature (Figure 4a). An optical photograph and a video showing the generation of bubbles of H2 and O2 at the cathode and anode, respectively, in the electrolyzer are provided as Figure S39 and Video S1 in the Supporting Information. After 10 h of electrolysis, the electrolyzer still exhibited high activity for overall water splitting, demonstrating its high stability in electrochemical processes over long time periods (Figure 4b). The Faraday efficiency of the two-electrode water electrolyzer was determined with chronoamperometry over 55 min time period (Figure S40, Supporting Information). The inset in Figure 4b showed that the H2 and O2 evolved experimentally as well as their molar ratio during this time were comparable with the theoretically calculated quantity. This gave ≈100% Faradic efficiency, and also suggested that the electrocatalytic reaction had high energy-conversion rate. These results further reveal that the as-obtained Co9S8@NOSC hybrid materials are promising bifunctional electrocatalysts for highly efficient and economical water-splitting electrolyzers.

sections.heading: 3. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, Co9S8@NOSC nanomaterials or electrocatalysts comprising only earth-abundant elements have been successfully
synthesized by pyrolyzing a solid-phase precursor comprising of S-Co-PPY. In particular, Co9S8@NOSC-900 nanocomposite material, which was synthesized at pyrolysis temperature of 900 °C, has been found to serve as a remarkable electrocatalyst for OER in alkaline medium with a small overpotential of 340 mV at current density of 10 mA cm−2, high anodic current density, low Tafel slope of 68 mV dec−1 as well as high (nearly 100%) Faradic efficiency. The excellent electrocatalytic activity toward OER exhibited by Co9S8@ NOSC has been ascribed to the synergistic effects between the heteroatom-doped carbon layers and the Co9S8 cores in the materials. Moreover, the materials have been shown to catalyze HER in acidic as well as basic solutions, with high efficiency in both cases and along with good stability in alkaline medium. The two-electrode electrolyzer assembled
using the material as electrocatalyst at both ends could afford current densities of 10 and 20 mA cm−2 at potentials of 1.60 and 1.74 V, respectively. This implies the great potential of the material as electrocatalyst for water splitting applications. We strongly believe that the work will inspire further research on the development of efficient, stable, earth-abundant, noble metal-free electrocatalysts for water splitting.
Supporting Information Supporting Information is available from the Wiley Online Library or from the author.

referenceMentions.context: [1] Among the available options, hydrogen (H2), a clean, carbon-free and renewable energy carrier, is regarded as one of the most ideal alternative energy carriers for the future, because it has a high gravimetric energy density, can be cleanly produced from water, and its only byproduct—after complete combustion/oxidation producing energy—is water.[2] However, the production of hydrogen is currently done by methane reforming reaction, which still relies on fossil fuels and suffers from similar energy challenges as other nonrenewable sectors.
Furthermore, a relatively weaker peak in the lower wavenumber region (at ≈670 cm−1) that can be attributed to Co9S8([15,25]) was observed.

metadata.abstractText: The continued rise in energy demand worldwide and our over-reliance on the limited supplies of fossil fuels (i.e., coal, petroleum, natural gas, etc.) as well as their continued negative environmental impacts have left researchers no choice but to delve into extensive searches for alternative energy options.[1] Among the available options, hydrogen (H2), a clean, carbon-free and renewable energy carrier, is regarded as one of the most ideal alternative energy carriers for the future, because it has a high gravimetric energy density, can be cleanly produced from water, and its only byproduct—after complete combustion/oxidation producing energy—is water.[2] However, the production of hydrogen is currently done by methane reforming reaction, which still relies on fossil fuels and suffers from similar energy challenges as other nonrenewable sectors.[3] On the contrary, the generation of hydrogen with electrochemical water splitting does not do so, especially if the energy driving the reaction comes from renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar energy. Hence, this reaction remains one of the most promising and appealing technologies for sustainable production of hydrogen from the clean, renewable, and abundant source of hydrogen, i.e., water. However, the wider application of this reaction is currently hampered by two major technical bottlenecks, namely (i) the kinetically and thermodynamically sluggish anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) in it and (ii) the instability, high cost, and less earth-abundance of noble metal-based materials, such as platinum and ruthenium(IV) oxide, which are commonly used as electrocatalysts in conventional water splitting electrolyzers.[4] So, low-cost, efficient, and stable noble metal-free OER electrocatalysts are extremely desired to accelerate the development of overall water splitting green energy conversion systems. Recently, some research efforts have been devoted to finding active and robust earth-abundant OER electrocatalysts with an ability to reduce the overpotential of the reaction, and thus make the water splitting process cost-effective and more energy-efficient. Among non-noble metal-based electrocatalysts, N-, O-, and S-Tridoped Carbon-Encapsulated Co9S8 Nanomaterials: Efficient Bifunctional Electrocatalysts for Overall Water Splitting
metadata.creator: Adobe InDesign CS6 (Macintosh)
